questions.text: The best suitable method of Biomedical waste disposal of yellow category wastes at a Primary Health Centre is-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Deep burial Incinerators require building space, manpower for operation, and relatively high investment and operating cost, which may not be possible at a PHC or a remote rural area Deep burial is a suitable method for disposal of yellow category waste at a PHC, especially in rural or remote areas where there is no access to common bio-medical waste treatment facility. questions.text: Which of the following Biomedical wastes can be incinerated?

Human anatomical wastes Incineration is a high-temperature dry oxygen process that reduces organic and combustible waste into the inorganic incombustible matter, significantly reducing waste volume and weight. questions.text: The best way to dispose of mercury is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Safe collection and reuse Although mercury is classified under chemical waste, it is also grouped under toxic, hazardous waste. Hence, its disposal differs from discharge into drains or burial in a secured landfill. Discharge into drains leads to accumulation in the drains of water treatment plants, causing water pollution and very high levels of treated water. Deep burial also leads to environmental pollution. Items containing mercury should never be sent to an incinerator as it causes the release of mercury vapors in the environment, which is toxic. Hence, special norms have been laid down for the disposal of merc,ury which may arise due to the breakage of a thermometer, sphygmomanometer, mercury tube lights, or mercury-containing materials like tooth amalgam generated at dental clinics or thiomersal-containing vaccines.. The best practice suggested for the disposal of mercury is its proper collection using specialized devices containing copper brush with which it forms amalgam, safe storage, and reuse—

options.label: A
options.text: Mixing biomedical waste with cement and other substance before disposal

options.label: B
options.text: Incineration of biomedical waste with cement and other substance before disposal

options.label: C
options.text: Dumping of Biomedical waste in sanitary landfills

questions.correct_answer: A. Mixing biomedical waste with cement and other substance before disposal
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mixing biomedical waste with cement and other substance before disposal Inertization involves mixing biomedical waste with cement and other substances before disposal to minimize the risk of toxi substances in waste contaminating ground/ surface water. Inertization is especially suitable for pharmaceuticals and for incineration ashes with high metal content A typical mixture composition is: 65% pharmaceutical waste 15% lime 15% cement 5% water. It is a relatively inexpensive technique though not suitable for infectious waste.
